comment._content: David Lyon Scott enlisted in the Gordon Highlanders as a Private soldier [Service Number 2197] and was quickly promoted to Corporal, commanding an infantry section. He was granted a temporary Commission into 4th Battalion Gordon Highlanders (Territorial Force note the 'T' on his collars) on 3rd December 1915. [LG Issue 29396 Page 12299 dated 7 Dec 1915]. He was the son of Mr and Mrs George Scott of Aberdeen. 4th Gordons website at: www.4thgordons.com/index.html contains the expurgated 8th Brigade Operations Order for the attack at Hooge (Second Bellewaarde) of 25th September 1915 (Scott is not listed here as wounded - but there is a LCpl 'Alexander' Scott listed as wounded on 7th October 1915 - son of Mr & Mrs James Scott of 24 Merkland Road, Aberdeen. He is noted as being wounded for the second time. Shrapnel to the shoulder and neck. Previous occupation - Painter): www.4thgordons.com/2Bellewaarde.html

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Following on from the 8th Brigade orders referred to above - the attack by 1st Battalion Gordon Highlanders - in 76th Brigade - is described as follows in The Official History of the War: Military Operations France & Belgium, 1917, Vol. VII, by C. Falls. (page 216/7):

"Under Brigadier General C.L. Porter of the 76th Brigade at Arras on 9 April 1917, ..... the 1st Battalion Gordon Highlanders took the German fourth line ..... [assaulting troops prepared to go over the top at 6.45pm and cleared the line of departure at 7pm] ..... the 1st Battalion Gordon Highlanders (still comparatively fresh) ..... passed through the 8th Brigade and assaulted under a barrage ..... The Gordons advanced gallantly and made some progress, but again [machine-gun] fire from Feuchy Chapel forced them back to the line of the Neuville - Feuchy Chapel road, where they dug in.

This was almost certainly the attack in which 2Lt Scott was killed.

Captain J C Dunn (2 RWF) gives an accurate description of the consequences of such an action "It was not unusual .. for a brigade to reach its objective with only 100 casualties, more or less, and have 1000 in falling back because the position was untenable, made so in part by its own failure to help clear its flanks during the advance." p. 339 'The War the Infantry Knew 1914-19'.//

comment._content:
The 1901 census shows him living at Ashgrove Rd, Ivy Bank, Aberdeen with his parents, George and Mary Ann Scott and 9 siblings ranging in age from 1-19. His father was a Watchmaker.

The National Probate Calendar states that he lived at 29 Richmond Hill Road, Aberdeen. The Medal Card shows that this is the address of David's father and indeed Probate was granted to George Scott, watchmaker and jeweller.
